content: Who was crowned first: Queen Elizabeth I or Queen Victoria?

Let's think about this. I know that Queen Elizabeth I and Queen Victoria were both prominent queens in British history, but I'm not exactly sure who came first. I remember that Elizabeth I was born in the 16th century, and Victoria was born later, in the 19th century. So, probably Elizabeth I was crowned first. But let me double-check the dates to be sure.

I think Elizabeth I was born in 1533 and she became queen in 1558, after the death of her half-sister Mary I. On the other hand, Queen Victoria was born in 1819 and she ascended to the throne in 1837 upon the death of her uncle, King William IV.

So, based on these dates, Queen Elizabeth I was crowned much earlier than Queen Victoria. Elizabeth I reigned from 1558 to 1603, while Victoria ruled from 1837 to 1901. That means Elizabeth I was the first to be crowned between the two.

But maybe there's more to it. Perhaps there was a time when both were queens in some capacity, or maybe there's a different way to look at their reigns. However, from what I know, Elizabeth I was definitely crowned first.

Let me see if there's any other perspective. Some people might get confused about the ordering of the queens, but in terms of chronology, Elizabeth I came before Victoria.

Also, it's interesting to note that Elizabeth I was the last monarch of the Tudor dynasty, while Victoria was the head of the House of Hanover, later the House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and then the House of Windsor.

So, in conclusion, Queen Elizabeth I was crowned first, centuries before Queen Victoria.

**Final Answer**

\[ \boxed{\text{Queen Elizabeth I was crowned first.}} \]
